SENT.plain: Dysphagia after lateral medullary infarction (LMI) is common
The dysphagia of LMI is dynamically characterized by a failure in triggering of the pharyngeal-phase swallowing movements, reduced output, and lack of coordination (swallowing pattern abnormality)
Based on accurate evaluation, we can select suitable rehabilitative approaches for individual patients, including respiratory therapy, food modification, postural changes, and oral care
We focused on the absence of upper esophageal sphincter (UES) opening of the unaffected side of the medullae
The movement pattern was defined as failure of bolus passage through the intact side of the UES, occurring at least once during the videofluorographic evaluation of each individual
Three abnormal patterns of UES opening were classified
The passage pattern abnormality shows the failure of the stereotyped motor sequence
For severe cases, it is necessary to consider long-term treatment, including botulinum toxin injection or surgery to prevent aspiration and adequate nutritional management
